name: Chuckwalla
description: Its appearance somewhat recalls monitor lizards—it lacks a dorsal crest, is stout, and has loose skin folds along the sides of its neck and belly. Coloration varies by sex and age. Adult males often have a black head and forelegs, while the body can be yellow, red, gray, or black. Females are less vividly colored.
food_note: Leaves, flowers, fruits, and other parts of desert plants; occasionally catches small invertebrates
image_alt: Chuckwalla, photo: Petr Velenský, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 28–43 cm, with tail length at least 50% of total length; weight up to 350 g
attractions: The chuckwalla is a diurnal lizard superbly adapted to desert conditions. It survives cooler periods in a state of torpor. Its smooth, flat body and flexible spine allow it to swiftly escape predators into rock crevices, where it inflates itself to wedge in place. During mating season (April to July), males temporarily become territorial, establishing a social hierarchy based on overall size. Females typically lay eggs once every two years, burying them in the soil.
breeding: Though there’s a record of one specimen in 1974, breeding began in 2004 when five individuals arrived, four from the wild. That same year, they started reproducing, and by the end of 2013, 111 hatchlings had emerged.
